title: Epidemiology - FQE Feb 2020 | Past Papers
description: KMTC Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Health Records and Information Technology - Epidemiology Paper, February 2020

questions.question: In the definition of epidemiology, the terms distribution and determinants taken together refer to:
questions.explanation: Explanation: Distribution: Refers to Frequency (how many) and Pattern (Time, Place, Person). Determinants: Refers to Causes and risk factors. Combined, they cover Option A.

options.text: a) Frequency, pattern and causes of health events
b) Dissemination of information to those who need to know
c) Knowledge, attitudes and practices related to health
d) Public health services and resources
e) Prevention and control of diseases

questions.question: Descriptive epidemiology includes all except:
questions.explanation: Explanation: Descriptive epidemiology covers Time (When), Place (Where), and Person (Who), and often the clinical characteristics (What). Why refers to the causes/determinants, which is the domain of Analytic Epidemiology.

questions.question: The time course of a disease outbreak is usually displayed as a/an:
questions.explanation: Explanation: An epidemic curve is a histogram that displays the number of new cases of disease over time during an outbreak.

questions.question: ID Number
questions.explanation: Explanation: An ID number is an administrative identifier, not a demographic characteristic (Who), time, or place.

questions.question: Disease code
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: a) What (clinical information) Explanation: The disease code identifies the diagnosis/health event.

questions.question: Race
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: d) Who (person) Explanation: Race is a demographic characteristic of the person.

questions.question: County
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: c) Where (place) Explanation: County describes the geographic location.

questions.question: Date of onset
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: b) When (time)

questions.question: Date of report
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: b) When (time)

questions.question: Outcome (alive or dead)
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: a) What (clinical information) Explanation: Outcome is part of the clinical progression/status of the disease event.

questions.question: When analyzing data by age the categories should be:
questions.explanation: Explanation: While 5-year groupings are standard, the optimal categorization depends on the disease epidemiology (e.g., Measles needs finer grouping in children than a chronic disease in adults). Option C is the most scientifically accurate principle.

options.text: a) The same for all diseases
b) 1 year, 1 to 4 years, 5 to 9 years, 10 to 14 years, 15 to 19 and 20 years for communicable diseases but not necessarily for chronic diseases.
c) Appropriate for each condition and narrow enough to detect any age-related patterns present in the data
d) 5 – year age groups for all diseases unless the data suggest the need for narrower categories to find a pattern or aberrancy

questions.question: Because socio economic status is difficult to quantify, we commonly use all the following substitute measures except: -
questions.explanation: Explanation: SES is typically measured by Education, Income, and Occupation. "Social standing" (or class) is often what we try to measure using the others, but subjective social standing is also a valid measure. Therefore, all are used.

questions.question: Public health surveillance includes which activities
questions.explanation: Explanation: The definition of surveillance is "The ongoing systematic collection, analysis, and interpretation of health data... closely integrated with the timely dissemination...". Intervention is the action taken based on surveillance, but is technically distinct from the surveillance process itself. If this is a "Select all that apply" question, it is A, B, C, D. If it is an "Except" question, the answer is E.

questions.question: The Framingham study, in which a group of residents have been followed since the 1950’s to identify occurrence and risk factors for heart disease is an example of which types of study: (circle all that apply)
questions.explanation: Explanation: The Framingham Heart Study is the classic example of a prospective Cohort study, which is a type of Observational study (no intervention was applied).

questions.question: The cancer and steroid hormone (CASH) study in which women with breast cancer and a comparable group of women without breast cancer were asked about their prior use of oral contraceptives (the pill) is an example of which type of study?
questions.explanation: Explanation: This is a Case-Control study (Cases = Breast Cancer, Controls = No Breast Cancer; looking back at exposure). Case-Control is not listed as a specific option, but it falls under Observational. "Case cohort" is a specific hybrid design, but this description fits standard Case-Control.

questions.question: The primary difference between an experimental and observational study is
questions.explanation: Explanation: In experimental studies (trials), the researcher assigns the exposure (e.g., drug vs placebo). In observational studies, the researcher simply observes exposures that occur naturally.

options.text: a) The investigator is blinded? (prevented from knowing the subjects’ true exposure status until the end of the study) in an experimental study
b) The investigator controls the subject’s exposure in an experimental study but not in an observational study
c) The investigator controls the subject’s outcome in an experimental study but not in an observational study
d) Experimental studies are conducted with animals; observational studies are conducted with humans

questions.question: The functions of public health surveillance include which of the following?
questions.explanation: Explanation: This question repeats the concept of Q13. All listed items are core functions.

questions.question: Using the natural history of disease timeline shown below, identify the usual time of diagnosis
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D (Stage of clinical disease) Explanation: Usual diagnosis occurs when symptoms appear, which defines the Stage of Clinical Disease. Screening can detect disease in Stage B, but "usual" diagnosis is in Stage D.

questions.question: Direct transmission includes which of the following modes of transmission?
questions.explanation: Explanation: Direct transmission includes direct contact and droplet spread (large particles, short range). Vehicles, vectors, airborne (droplet nuclei), and water are forms of Indirect transmission.

questions.question: An epidemic curve which follows the classic log-normal pattern of sharp rise and more gradual decline is most consistent with which manner of spread?
questions.explanation: Explanation: A Point Source epidemic (like food poisoning) typically shows a sharp rise to a peak (as everyone is exposed at once) followed by a log-normal (gradual) decline.

questions.question: Both incidence and prevalence can be represented by the formula (x/y) x 10^n for a specified time period. The primary difference between incidence and prevalence is in
questions.explanation: Explanation: - Incidence: x = Number of NEW cases. - Prevalence: x = Number of EXISTING (new + old) cases. - While 'y' (denominator) also changes slightly (population at risk vs total population), the fundamental distinction is whether you are counting events (new cases) or states (existing cases).

options.text: d) The time period of reference

questions.question: Both point prevalence and period prevalence can be represented by the formula (x/y) x 10^n for a specified time period. The primary difference between point prevalence and period prevalence is in:
questions.explanation: Explanation: - Point Prevalence: Time period is a single point (e.g., "Do you smoke now?"). - Period Prevalence: Time period is an interval (e.g., "Have you smoked in the last year?").

options.text: d) The time period of reference

questions.question: In a recent survey, investigators found that the prevalence of disease A was higher than the prevalence of disease B. The incidence and seasonal pattern of both diseases are similar. Explanations consistent with this observation include:
questions.explanation: Explanation: Prevalence ($P$) depends on Incidence ($I$) and Duration ($D$) ($P \approx I \times D$). If $I$ is equal, for $P_A > P_B$, disease A must have a longer duration than B. - b) If patients recover quickly from B, B's duration is short, so $P_B$ is low. Consistent. - d) If patients die quickly from B, B's duration is short, so $P_B$ is low. Consistent. - a) and c) would make A's duration short, reducing $P_A$, which contradicts the finding.

options.text: a) Patients recover more quickly from disease A than from disease B
b) Patients recover more quickly from disease B than from disease A
c) Patients die quickly from disease A but not from disease B
d) Patients die quickly from disease B but not from disease A

questions.question: A recent train derailment at Kibera in Nairobi exposed residents of the slum community to a chemical hazard. Many residents became ill, some died. To calculate the probability or risk of illness, which denominator would you use?
questions.explanation: Explanation: Risk (Cumulative Incidence) uses the population at risk at the start of the observation period as the denominator.

options.text: a) The size of the population at risk at the beginning of the period
b) The size of the population at risk at the mid-point of the period
c) The size of the population at risk at the end of the period
d) The average size of the population at risk during the period
e) None of the above except guessing

questions.question: During the Christmas week, 87 persons in a small community (population = 460) attended a social event which included a meal prepared by several of the participants. Within 3 days, 39 of the participants became ill with a condition diagnosed as salmonellosis. The attack rate among participants was:
questions.explanation: Calculation: $$ \text{Attack Rate} = \frac{\text{Ill}}{\text{Exposed (Participants)}} \times 100 $$ $$ \text{Attack Rate} = \frac{39}{87} \times 100 = 44.8\% $$ Note: The total community population (460) is irrelevant as they were not at the event (not exposed).

options.text: e) Cannot be calculated from the information given

questions.question: In a community of 800 households (population = 4799), public health authorities found 120 persons with condition D in 80 households. A total of 480 persons lived in the 80 affected households. Assuming that each household had only one primary case, the secondary attack rate is
questions.explanation: Calculation: Total cases: 120 Primary cases: 1 per household * 80 households = 80 cases. Secondary cases: Total (120) - Primary (80) = 40 cases. Susceptible contacts: Total pop in affected households (480) - Primary cases (80) = 400. Secondary Attack Rate (SAR): (Secondary Cases / Susceptible Contacts) * 100 SAR = (40 / 400) * 100 = 10%.

questions.question: A questionnaire was administered to the persons who attended a funeral of an assistant chief in a sub location. The two by two table shown below summarizes the relationship between consumption of potato salad and illness. The best estimate of the relative risk is approximately:
questions.explanation: Calculation: Incidence in Exposed ($I_e$): $a / (a+b) = 36 / 48 = 0.75$ Incidence in Unexposed ($I_u$): $c / (c+d) = 3 / 39 = 0.0769$ Relative Risk (RR): $I_e / I_u = 0.75 / 0.0769 \approx 9.75$

questions.question: Of the following mortality rates, which one uses the same denominator
questions.explanation: Explanation: - Crude Mortality Rate uses the Total Mid-Year Population. - Cause-Specific Mortality Rate (deaths from X / Total Pop) also uses the Total Mid-Year Population. - Age/Sex/Race specific rates use only the population of that specific subgroup (e.g., Pop > 65, Female Pop). Therefore, Crude and Cause-specific rates share the same denominator.

questions.question: Tables, graphs and charts are important tools for which tasks of an epidemiologist?
questions.explanation: Explanation: While they are used for presentation (d), their primary analytical role is summarizing data patterns (Time, Place, Person) in descriptive epidemiology (b).

questions.question: How does public health surveillance differ from medical surveillance?
questions.explanation: Explanation: The key distinction in epidemiology vs. clinical medicine is the focus: Population vs. Individual.

options.text: a) Those who conduct public health surveillance are generally not physicians
b) Public health surveillance refers to monitoring of populations, while medical surveillance refers to monitoring of individuals
c) Public health surveillance is generally based on a laboratory – confirmed diagnosis
d) Public health surveillance comes from the public clinics, while medical surveillance comes from private health care providers
e) There is no difference between them

questions.question: Vital statistics are important sources of date on
questions.explanation: Explanation: Vital statistics systems register vital events: Births, Deaths (Mortality), Marriages, and Divorces. Morbidity (Illness) data usually comes from disease surveillance or hospital records, not the civil registration/vital stats system.

questions.question: Important sources of morbidity data include:
questions.explanation: Explanation: Notifiable disease reports (surveillance) are the primary source for specific communicable diseases. Hospital data and lab data are also sources. Vital records (d) are for mortality. If choosing the best single answer for epidemiology, it's usually a) Notifiable disease reports.

questions.question: Surveillance activities focused on animal population are not usually intended to
questions.explanation: Explanation: Animal surveillance (e.g., for rabies, avian flu) complements human surveillance by providing early warnings (One Health approach), but it does not substitute for monitoring human disease.

options.text: a) Detect changes in the size and distribution of reservoir populations
b) Detect changes in the size and distribution of vector populations
c) Detect disease agents which might be present
d) Detect epizootics (outbreaks of disease in animals)
e) Substitute for surveillance of morbidity in humans

questions.question: Active surveillance is characterized by: -
questions.explanation: Explanation: In Active Surveillance, public health staff actively visit or call facilities to solicit reports, rather than waiting for them to arrive (Passive).

options.text: a) Health care providers taking the initiative to contact the health department
b) The health department taking the initiative to contact health care providers
c) The health department taking the initiative to track down contacts of case patients
d) The health department taking the initiative to identify undetected cases through serosurveys
e) The health department taking the initiative to monitor potentially exposed individuals to detect early signs of disease

questions.question: The minimum number of human cases necessary for a health department action such as an investigation or control activities is:
questions.explanation: Explanation: For rare, highly fatal, or eliminated diseases (e.g., Polio, Ebola), a single case is an outbreak requiring action. For common diseases, the threshold is higher.

options.text: b) Two times the expected number
c) Variable, depending on the disease, but at least two cases
d) Variable, depending on the disease, but could be one or zero
e) Variable, depending on public concern and political pressure

questions.question: The ability of a surveillance system to detect the cases it is intended to detect is referred to as: -
questions.explanation: Explanation: Sensitivity in surveillance is the proportion of true cases in the population that are detected and reported by the system.

questions.question: Public health officials have recently taken action to overcome a common limitation of the notifiable disease reporting system. This limitation is:
questions.explanation: Explanation: Underreporting is the most significant and common limitation of passive surveillance systems.

options.text: b) Lack of representativeness of reported cases

questions.question: The Ministry of Health sometimes adds a disease to the notifiable disease list even if no effective control measures are available. This action is justifiable if:
questions.explanation: Explanation: Even without immediate control measures, collecting data on a new disease helps understand its patterns, risk factors, and natural history, which is essential for developing future control strategies.

options.text: a) The health department is well staffed and can handle the addition without compromising its other activities
b) The disease is on the notifiable disease list of a neighbouring state with a similar population
c) The disease is new and surveillance reports may shed light on its epidemiology
d) The incidence of the disease has been steadily increasing

questions.question: If the Health Information department decides to improve their reporting system, the one best stop to do this is:
questions.explanation: Explanation: WHO guidelines suggest that for a surveillance system to be effective, it should be simple and focused. However, Option B (Education/Role clarity) is also a critical step. Usually, simplifying (C) improves compliance and quality most effectively in overburdened systems.

options.text: a) Require more disease specific forms from local health department
b) Make sure all persons with a responsibility to report understands their role clearly
c) Narrow the focus of the reporting system down to a manageable amount of health events depending on the staff and resources
d) Shift the burden for report generations from the health department to the health care provider

questions.question: In an ongoing outbreak of a disease with no known source and mode of transmission, the primary reason for an investigation relates to:
questions.explanation: Explanation: The ultimate goal of any outbreak investigation, especially for an unknown disease, is to identify the source/mode of transmission so that measures can be implemented to prevent further spread and control the outbreak.

options.text: c) Learning more about the disease
d) Being responsive to the concerns of the community

questions.question: The following data was obtained from a survey conducted in Nakuru town to determine whether smoking should be banned among the youths in Kenya. Category Death rates from lung cancer per 1000 persons aged 30 or more per year I Non-smokers 0.07 II Cigarette smokers 0.96 a) From the data above, compute: i) Relative risk of smokers versus non-smokers (5 marks) ii) Attributable risk of smokers versus non-smokers (3 marks) iii) Explain your answers in (a) above in narrative form (4 marks) b) What are the uses of relative risk to? i) The clinician ii) The researcher c) What are the uses of attributable risk? i) To the physician responsible for prevention programs? (5 marks) ii) To the physician responsible for health planning for large groups (5 marks) (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: a) Computations: i) Relative Risk (RR): $$ RR = \frac{\text{Rate in Exposed (Smokers)}}{\text{Rate in Unexposed (Non-smokers)}} $$ $$ RR = \frac{0.96}{0.07} = 13.7 $$ ii) Attributable Risk (AR): $$ AR = \text{Rate in Exposed} - \text{Rate in Unexposed} $$ $$ AR = 0.96 - 0.07 = 0.89 \text{ deaths per 1000 persons per year} $$ iii) Explanation: Relative Risk (13.7): Smokers are 13.7 times more likely to die from lung cancer than non-smokers. This indicates a very strong association. Attributable Risk (0.89/1000): Among smokers, 0.89 deaths per 1000 persons per year can be attributed specifically to smoking. If smoking were eliminated, 0.89 deaths per 1000 smokers could be prevented. b) Uses of Relative Risk: Clinician: Helps in counseling patients about the magnitude of risk associated with a behavior (e.g., "You are 14 times more likely to die if you smoke"). Researcher: Used to assess the strength of association between exposure and disease, helping to establish causality. c) Uses of Attributable Risk: i) Prevention Programs: It shows the potential impact of an intervention. It quantifies the excess disease burden that could be eliminated if the risk factor (smoking) is removed. ii) Health Planning: It helps in resource allocation by estimating the public health impact. It tells planners how many lives can be saved or cases prevented in the community, guiding priority setting.

options.text: Relative Risk (13.7): Smokers are 13.7 times more likely to die from lung cancer than non-smokers. This indicates a very strong association.

Attributable Risk (0.89/1000): Among smokers, 0.89 deaths per 1000 persons per year can be attributed specifically to smoking. If smoking were eliminated, 0.89 deaths per 1000 smokers could be prevented.

questions.question: Table 1: Prevalence and incidence of selected neurological diseases at Kenyatta National Hospital, Nairobi Kenya. Diagnosis Rates per 100,000 population Prevalence Incidence i) Epilepsy 69 17.3 ii) Multiple sclerosis 376 30.8 iii) Parkinson's disease 157 20.0 iv) Motor neuron disease 55 5.0 v) CNS Neoplasms 7 1.7 a) From the data in table 1 above obtained from Health Records and Information department, compute the average duration, in years of the five chronic neurological conditions listed (15 marks) b) In a recent survey conducted in Nairobi city it was found that male street children aged below 20 who are heavy smokers have relative risk for lung cancer of 10. Given that the absolute risk for lung cancer of parking boys of the same age who do not smoke is 0.1 per 1000, compute the probability of a male street boy (smoker) aged below 20 developing lung cancer per year (5 marks) (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: a) Average Duration Calculation: Formula: $Prevalence \approx Incidence \times Duration \rightarrow Duration = \frac{Prevalence}{Incidence}$ Epilepsy: $69 / 17.3 \approx 3.99 \text{ years}$ Multiple Sclerosis: $376 / 30.8 \approx 12.21 \text{ years}$ Parkinson's Disease: $157 / 20.0 = 7.85 \text{ years}$ Motor Neuron Disease: $55 / 5.0 = 11.0 \text{ years}$ CNS Neoplasms: $7 / 1.7 \approx 4.12 \text{ years}$ b) Probability Calculation: Given: Relative Risk (RR) = 10 Given: Incidence in Unexposed ($I_u$) = 0.1 per 1000 Formula: $RR = \frac{I_e}{I_u}$ We need $I_e$ (Incidence in Exposed/Smokers): $10 = \frac{I_e}{0.1}$ $I_e = 10 \times 0.1 = 1.0$ Answer: The probability (absolute risk) is 1.0 per 1000 per year.

questions.question: Dr. Mohammed is a County Director of Health Services in Kwale County of Coast region. The county serves a population of 120,000. He spends all his time at the hospital where he handles essentially curative cases. Last month (January) alone, he treated many children suffering from diarrhea. All of them were from Kinango sub-county situated 35 kilometers from the country referral hospital. Dr. Mohammed has no information on Kinango which he last visited two years before. He likes curative care so much that he hardly moves out to supervise the health facilities in his area of jurisdiction or to attend health committee meetings. Therefore, he has no information on the population that his hospital is supposed to cover. a) In your own opinion, why does Dr. Mohammed behave the way he does? b) In reality, does this happen? Gives reasons for your answer c) What information should Dr. Mohammed have on the health of his community? d) How can he obtain the information in 'C' above? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: a) Reasons for Dr. Mohammed's Behavior: Clinical Bias: He likely has a clinical background (doctor/clinician) rather than public health training, leading to a focus on individual treatment ("Curative bias"). Lack of Resources: He may lack transport, fuel, or staffing to conduct field visits or supervision. Understaffing: If he is the only doctor, he may be overwhelmed by the patient load at the referral hospital, leaving no time for administrative duties. Lack of Motivation/Incentives: Poor supervision from national level or lack of allowances for field work. b) Reality Check: Yes, this is very common in reality. Reasons: Shortage of Health Workers: Managers often have to double as clinicians due to staff shortages. Poor Funding: Public health activities (prevention, supervision) are often underfunded compared to curative services (drugs, equipment). Training Gaps: Many managers are appointed based on clinical seniority, not management or epidemiological competence. c) Essential Health Information Needed: Demographics: Population size, age/sex distribution, density in Kinango. Morbidity/Mortality Data: Top causes of illness and death (e.g., Diarrhea incidence rates). Environmental Factors: Water sources, sanitation coverage (latrines) in Kinango. Health Service Coverage: Immunization rates, facility utilization, staffing levels in peripheral facilities. Social Determinants: Poverty levels, education, cultural practices affecting health. d) Methods to Obtain Information: Routine Health Information System (DHIS2): Review monthly reports from Kinango health facilities. Surveillance Reports: Check IDSR (Integrated Disease Surveillance and Response) data for outbreaks. Field Visits/Supervision: Conduct supportive supervision visits to Kinango. Community Health Volunteers (CHVs): Gather reports from Level 1 community units. Surveys: Conduct rapid assessments or household surveys in the affected area. Stakeholder Meetings: Attend health committee meetings to hear from community representatives.

options.text: Clinical Bias: He likely has a clinical background (doctor/clinician) rather than public health training, leading to a focus on individual treatment ("Curative bias").
Lack of Resources: He may lack transport, fuel, or staffing to conduct field visits or supervision.
Understaffing: If he is the only doctor, he may be overwhelmed by the patient load at the referral hospital, leaving no time for administrative duties.
Lack of Motivation/Incentives: Poor supervision from national level or lack of allowances for field work.
